speaker: CARNIVAL WORKER
line: Mr. Maleeni... Hey, guy. You ready to rumble?

speaker: MALEENI
line: If by "rumble," you mean "perform..." yes, I am.

speaker: CARNIVAL WORKER
line: Cool. Uh, you know how they said you get $125 for the day? It's going to be $75 instead. The gate's for crap. But, hey, the show's got to go on, right?

speaker: MALEENI
line: This will be my greatest show ever.

speaker: CARNIVAL WORKER
line: Right on.

speaker: MALEENI
line: Ladies and gentlemen, damas y caballeros... I aim today not just to entertain, but to educate. To instruct and inform in the venerable and ancient history of my art. Until Johann Nepomuk Hofsinzer called playing cards "the poetry of magic" a conjurer's skill was determined entirely by his ability to perform one effect. That effect was known as "the cups and balls." The games were known for hundreds if not thousands of years. Perhaps the greatest performer was the Italian, Bartolomeo Bosco.

speaker: HECKLER DUDE
line: Get on with it!

speaker: MALEENI
line: Bosco's passes with the cups and balls. Wah-day... Chubio... Colerader. Three gone... And yet, three return. Bosco had only one contemporary rival a slightly older Frenchman named Conus, who announced in 1795 that he would make his wife, who was five-foot-seven appear under one of the cups. Practice though I have, I have been unable even to get married.

speaker: MALEENI
line: Conus placed one ball in his pocket. He put the second ball away. Putting the third ball in his hand he made it vanish and that's the mystery of the cups... and the balls.

speaker: HECKLER DUDE
line: Yo. Can't you do anything that ain't a hundred years old? That ain't old school, that's decrepit.

speaker: MALEENI
line: Young man, shall I come heckle you on your job? Make sure you count out the requisite number of McNuggets?

speaker: HECKLER DUDE
line: Show me something. Come on... show me something!

speaker: MALEENI
line: A callow challenge to be met by experience... and skill. To wit, the Egyptian, Dedi, whose most celebrated feat was to reattach a recently-severed head reuniting it with a still-warm body and no harm done. Western history knows three previous attempts at recreating this Noachian feat... each of the three ending in tragedy. This will be the fourth. May I have complete silence, please?

speaker: CROWD
line: Yeah! Senor Maleeni! Woo-hoo!

speaker: ANNOUNCER
line: Let's give it up for the Amazing Maleeni.

speaker: CARNIVAL WORKER
line: Guy, you rock! That kicked ass! I mean, it looked completely real! How did you do that? Oh, yeah, right-- magic. Oh, hey, your money-- hold up.

speaker: CARNIVAL WORKER
line: Two, four, 50, 55, 60, 65, 70, 75. You earned it.

speaker: CARNIVAL WORKER
line: Mr. Maleeni?

speaker: CARNIVAL WORKER
line: Mr. Maleeni.

speaker: CARNIVAL WORKER
line: Oh, God...

speaker: MULDER
line: Neat trick, huh?

speaker: SCULLY
line: I can think of a neater one. How you convinced me to drop everything and get on the first plane to Los Angeles.

speaker: MULDER
line: Come on, Scully. This isn't intriguing enough for you? A magician turns his head completely around 360 degrees to the delight of young and old alike after which it plops unceremoniously onto the pier... see the picture?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Yeah, I saw the picture. And as for this Amazing Maleeni turning his head all the way around,

speaker: LIKE YOU SAID, MULDER
line: neat trick.

speaker: MULDER
line: But...

speaker: SCULLY
line: But... I'd guess this event was completely removed from the subsequent murder.

speaker: MULDER
line: You think this was a murder?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Don't you?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder, his head was cut off.

speaker: MULDER
line: Ah, observe the nearly complete absence of blood. Observe the paucity of fingerprints as evidenced by the LAPD's liberal use of lycopodium powder.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Why are you talking like Tony Randall?

speaker: MULDER
line: Know that the Amazing Maleeni was alive one moment and expired the next. Know also that no one saw his fleeing attacker nor heard the dying man's cries.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder, I admit that I don't know how it happened but I still say that it was a murder. So what's your theory?

speaker: MULDER
line: A magic trick gone horribly wrong. One that claims the lives of all who attempt it.

speaker: MULDER
line: Can I see that camcorder again? Thank you. A tourist videotaped Maleeni's performance. Look at this.

speaker: HECKLER DUDE
line: That ain't old school, that's decrepit!

speaker: SCULLY
line: Who's the heckler?

speaker: HECKLER DUDE
line: Come on, show me something!

speaker: MULDER
line: I don't know.

speaker: MULDER
line: Neat trick, huh?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Hang on a second. Let me see this. That heckler was pretty hard to impress wouldn't you say? Look, and then he just takes off in a huff.

speaker: MULDER
line: What, you think he's a murderer?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Well, it's worth checking out, don't you think?

speaker: MULDER
line: That'll be a neat trick in itself. You never see his face.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Ah, but observe. His discarded soda cup. The hand may be quicker than the eye but it still leaves fingerprints.

speaker: MULDER
line: Provided they haven't dumped the trash.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Skeptic.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mr. LaBonge? We're Agents Mulder and Scully from the FBI.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Were you at the, uh, Santa Monica Pier yesterday morning?

speaker: LABONGE
line: Yeah.

speaker: MULDER
line: You attended a magic show. The Amazing Maleeni.

speaker: LABONGE
line: Yeah, he sucks. Why?

speaker: SCULLY
line: He's dead, under extremely suspicious circumstances.

speaker: LABONGE
line: He still sucks. How'd you find me?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Your fingerprints. You have a criminal record.

speaker: MULDER
line: A conviction for pick pocketing.

speaker: LABONGE
line: Man, that was performance art. And besides, it's ancient history. What are you saying, you think I killed him?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Well, you're on videotape heckling the deceased.

speaker: MULDER
line: What did you have against Mr. Maleeni?

speaker: LABONGE
line: First of all... his name's not Maleeni. That's the name of a real magician, a guy at the turn of the century, Max Malini. Ever hear of him?

speaker: SCULLY
line: No.

speaker: LABONGE
line: That's too bad; you should have. Anyway, he steals his name, spells it a little differently and he does some tired crap that wouldn't cut it at a kid's birthday party.

speaker: MULDER
line: What about the trick where he turns his head completely around?

speaker: LABONGE
line: Check it out.

speaker: LABONGE
line: No problem. Did you like that?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Yeah.

speaker: LABONGE
line: Watch. Coin in the hand... blows away. Maybe it's a little bit hard for you to see. Let me make that... Bigger for you.

speaker: MULDER
line: Those are great, but I don't see how they're any different or better than the ones Maleeni did.

speaker: LABONGE
line: Mozart and Salieri. They sound pretty much the same to a layman. But they ain't. You know what I'm saying? It's about... originality. Style. And more than anything else... soul. Because that's what separates the great ones... from the hacks. We can't do this halfway. We're dealing with powerful forces at work here. Energies far beyond our mere... mortal... understanding.

speaker: MULDER
line: Enough to make a magician lose his head?

speaker: LABONGE
line: Could be. That, and I hear Maleeni racked up some pretty big gambling debts. Who knows who he might've pissed off.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Well, thank you, Mr. LaBonge. We'll, uh... be in touch.

speaker: LABONGE
line: Please do. Oh, and agents...

speaker: MULDER
line: Mozart and Salieri. Which one's which?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder, I think that professional jealousy is as good a motive for murder as any.

speaker: MULDER
line: If it was a murder. I'm not convinced.

speaker: SCULLY
line: If I can get Mr. Maleeni into an autopsy bay hopefully we can put this issue to a rest as soon as possible.

speaker: SCULLY
line: All right, I'm stumped... and I think I'm supposed to be.

speaker: MULDER
line: What do you think?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Well, first of all, and sorry to disappoint you but, uh, Mr. Maleeni's head didn't just magically fall off. It was very carefully sawed. Very slow and exacting work probably with a fine-tooth meat saw. And check out this little detail.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Spirit gum, Mulder. It held the head to the body. Just barely, of course.

speaker: MULDER
line: So he was murdered.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Well, no. As far as I can tell this man died of advanced coronary disease.

speaker: MULDER
line: Natural causes.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Yeah.

speaker: MULDER
line: So, basically he died of a heart attack, somebody crept up behind him, sawed his head off and then glued it back on all in the space of 30 seconds. Does that make sense to you?

speaker: SCULLY
line: No. Which makes it even stranger still because, as far as I can tell this body has been dead for over a month. I see signs of refrigeration.

speaker: MULDER
line: And yet he performed yesterday. What a trouper.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Well, somebody performed yesterday.

speaker: LABONGE
line: Cissy Alvarez.

speaker: ALVEREZ
line: Who are you?

speaker: LABONGE
line: You don't remember me. Ain't that a bitch. My name's LaBonge. I did time with you about eight years ago. You were in for bank robbery.

speaker: ALVEREZ
line: The name doesn't mean anything. What do you want?

speaker: LABONGE
line: I hear you're a poker player. You won big off a guy who calls himself the Amazing Maleeni. Also goes by the name of Herman Pinchbeck.

speaker: ALVEREZ
line: Pinchbeck?

speaker: LABONGE
line: He's dead.

speaker: ALVEREZ
line: Yeah, I saw in the paper. Something about his head fell off. What's it to you?

speaker: LABONGE
line: I'm the guy that made his head fall off.

speaker: LABONGE
line: You took his marker, right? What did he owe you? 15 grand?

speaker: LABONGE
line: I don't think he was ever going to pay you back.

speaker: ALVEREZ
line: You want to cut to the chase? You know, get a little more of your story out before we stomp you to death?

speaker: LABONGE
line: How would you like to get back what you're owed? Times ten.

speaker: LABONGE
line: Helping me.

speaker: ALVEREZ
line: Do what?

speaker: LABONGE
line: Magic.

speaker: LABONGE
line: Want to hear more?

speaker: MULDER
line: Excuse me. I'm looking for Mr. Albert Pinchbeck.

speaker: FEMALE BANK EMPLOYEE
line: He's the gentleman right over there. The poor man.

speaker: MULDER
line: He look familiar to you, Scully?

speaker: SCULLY
line: He certainly does.

speaker: MULDER
line: The plot thickens.

speaker: SCULLY
line: He might try and run.

speaker: PINCHBECK
line: Come in. Good morning, Mr. And Mrs...?

speaker: MULDER
line: Agents... Mulder and Scully. FBI.

speaker: PINCHBECK
line: You're not here for a home loan, I take it.

speaker: SCULLY
line: No. We are investigating the death of a magician who called himself the Amazing Maleeni.

speaker: PINCHBECK
line: Herman Pinchbeck, my twin brother.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Yes, we know. We checked his next of kin.

speaker: MULDER
line: What happened to your neck, Mr. Pinchbeck?

speaker: PINCHBECK
line: I was in a car accident.

speaker: MULDER
line: Car accident. So your injured neck has nothing to do with a magic trick you performed at the Santa Monica Pier two days ago? One which involved you turning your head around 360 degrees?

speaker: PINCHBECK
line: No. That wasn't me. I was in a bad car accident in Mexico.

speaker: MULDER
line: Oh, bad Mexican car accident. In Mexico.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Do you know magic, Mr. Pinchbeck?

speaker: PINCHBECK
line: Yes, I do. Back in the '70s, my brother and I performed together.

speaker: MULDER
line: Why did you stop?

speaker: PINCHBECK
line: You never really stop.

speaker: MULDER
line: Pick a card, any card?

speaker: MULDER
line: Hmm. Very impressive.

speaker: PINCHBECK
line: My brother and I both wanted to do the absolute best magic the world had ever seen. The difference was I knew he'd never get there but he always believed we would. We didn't talk much after I quit the act.

speaker: MULDER
line: I have a theory, Mr. Pinchbeck and I'm going to tell you how it goes. I think that your brother Herman died of heart disease having never made it as the world's greatest magician and I think that hurt you just as your estrangement from him hurt you. And I think what you did was perform his last act for him-- -- one last act for which he'd always be remembered-- one last act that would end with such a shock, such a denouement as would be forever remembered in the annals of magic. That's what I think.

speaker: PINCHBECK
line: I so wish that were true.

speaker: PINCHBECK
line: It was a very bad car accident in Mexico. MULDER is VERY embarrassed.)

speaker: MULDER
line: Oy.

speaker: SCULLY
line: No kidding. What now?

speaker: MULDER
line: A guy's head falls off. It's the greatest trick in the world. Only there's no discernible point to it. What's the reason for doing that in the first place?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Why do people do magic? To, uh, impress, to delight to gain attention.

speaker: MULDER
line: This one's gained mostly police attention. Maybe that's the point.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Well, maybe we should consult an expert. Someone who knows magic, who's seen the greatest trick in the world. Maybe he can help us figure that out.

speaker: MULDER
line: Mozart.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Yeah.

speaker: LABONGE
line: What's in it for me? I mean, let's say I help you out. What do I get in return?

speaker: SCULLY
line: The feeling of pride that comes from performing your civic duty.

speaker: MULDER
line: How about the chance to root through the professional secrets of your least favorite magician?

speaker: LABONGE
line: Good for a laugh, I guess.

speaker: LABONGE
line: Man, it's worse than I thought.

speaker: LABONGE
line: You got to feed those things, you know.

speaker: LABONGE
line: So... Maleeni wasn't murdered?

speaker: SCULLY
line: It would seem not.

speaker: LABONGE
line: So someone impersonated him and his crappy act. It's impressive.

speaker: LABONGE
line: I'd say the twin brother did it but I don't think he's any better a magician than Maleeni was...

speaker: MULDER
line: There's that, and he's got no legs.

speaker: LABONGE
line: Yeah. Whatever. Anyway, we're looking for a magician with the same height and build... a good makeup job and the right wig and no one would know the difference.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Not even you, I guess.

speaker: LABONGE
line: I had a couple of Jell-O shots in me.

speaker: MULDER
line: How did this impersonator switch out the dead body?

speaker: LABONGE
line: With ease. You're going to kick yourselves when I show you how he did this, it's so simple. 'Cause magic is all about... … misdirection.

speaker: LABONGE
line: Your impersonator simply made sure everyone was looking the other way when he pulled Maleeni's body from its secret hiding place underneath... the floor.

speaker: LABONGE
line: Man, this guy's good.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Thanks for your expert opinion. I guess we're right back where we started.

speaker: MULDER
line: Maybe not. You said that, uh, the Amazing Maleeni had some gambling debts?

speaker: LABONGE
line: Yeah, that's what I heard.

speaker: MULDER
line: Check this out. It looks like a marker. $20,000. Pinchbeck.

speaker: SCULLY
line: What would this be doing in Maleeni's van?

speaker: COURIER GUARD
line: Thank you, Mr. Pinchbeck. If you could sign here for me.

speaker: PINCHBECK
line: With pleasure.

speaker: PINCHBECK
line: Anthony, what kind of gun is that?

speaker: ANTHONY THE COURIER GUARD
line: Glock 17. Nine millimeter.

speaker: PINCHBECK
line: I've been thinking of maybe buying one since my accident.

speaker: ANTHONY THE COURIER GUARD
line: Here-- take a look.

speaker: PINCHBECK
line: Gosh, it's, uh... it's heavier than I would have thought. Thank you, Anthony... Marvin.

speaker: ANTHONY THE COURIER GUARD
line: If you ever want I'll take you to the shooting range. Have a good one, Mr. Pinchbeck.

speaker: PINCHBECK
line: You, too.

speaker: PINCHBECK
line: Hello. May I help you?

speaker: ALVAREZ
line: Damn. You look just like him.

speaker: PINCHBECK
line: I'm sorry?

speaker: ALVAREZ
line: Your no-good, malapaga brother died owing me money. A lot of money. You're going to make good.

speaker: PINCHBECK
line: I'm sorry, but my, uh, brother's debts are his own.

speaker: ALVAREZ
line: I said, you're going to make good, 'cause me and my friends, we know where you live.

speaker: MARVIN THE COURIER GUARD
line: That sound like the rear diff?

speaker: ANTHONY THE COURIER GUARD
line: Pull over. Stay here and, uh, call it in. I'll check it out.

speaker: MARVIN THE COURIER GUARD
line: We got a problem with the rear diff. Fourth and main, checking it out...

speaker: ANTHONY THE COURIER GUARD
line: You! In the truck! Get up where I can see you! Hands where I can see them! Up! Hands up!

speaker: ANTHONY THE COURIER GUARD
line: All right, get out! Mister, get out...

speaker: ANTHONY THE COURIER GUARD
line: I got a guy down back here!

speaker: ANTHONY THE COURIER GUARD
line: It was a guy with tattoos! I shot him four times! I don't understand. He was right here.

speaker: SCULLY
line: It's your handwriting, is it not? Mr. Alvarez please answer the question.

speaker: ALVAREZ
line: That ain't mine. I don't know where you got that.

speaker: MULDER
line: Interesting. Yours are the only fingerprints on it.

speaker: SCULLY
line: We ran it through the California criminal history database to which you seem to be quite well known.

speaker: ALVAREZ
line: So it's my marker. So Pinchbeck owed me money. It was a friendly game of poker.

speaker: MULDER
line: Very friendly. $20,000 friendly.

speaker: ALVAREZ
line: Where did you find that?

speaker: SCULLY
line: In Herman Pinchbeck's van. Where were you last Thursday?

speaker: ALVAREZ
line: Here. All day. Ask them. What is it you think I did to Pinchbeck, huh? What's in it for me? If I kill him, he ain't going to pay me.

speaker: MULDER
line: Why did you play with him in the first place? You knew he was a professional magician.

speaker: ALVAREZ
line: I didn't know what he was... and he sure as hell couldn't play worth a damn.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Don't leave town, Mr. Alvarez.

speaker: MULDER
line: Don't you find it odd that the amazing Maleeni's a lousy poker player? I mean, this is a guy who's adept at manipulating cards.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Maybe he wasn't so adept. LaBonge certainly doesn't have a high opinion of his skills.

speaker: MULDER
line: There's another possibility. Behold-- an ordinary household quarter. I'm going to take the quarter from my right hand and place it into my left hand. Where is it?

speaker: SCULLY
line: It's in your right hand.

speaker: MULDER
line: Oh, no, no, no.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Ah... That's not bad.

speaker: MULDER
line: Blow your nose, Scully.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder...

speaker: MULDER
line: Blow your nose.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Ah-choo.

speaker: MULDER
line: Ta-da.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Amazing!

speaker: MULDER
line: The great Muldeeni.

speaker: SCULLY
line: And what's the point?

speaker: MULDER
line: It's misdirection. That's the heart of magic. I made you look one direction. The quarter went in the other.

speaker: SCULLY
line: And that's what's happening in this case?

speaker: MULDER
line: I think we're being led around by our noses.

speaker: SCULLY
line: By whom? Maleeni is already dead.

speaker: MULDER
line: It certainly would appear so, but then again, you thought the quarter was in the right hand.

speaker: LABONGE
line: Yeah, hello? Yeah, I want to report a man with a gun. H-h- he's threatening to kill somebody.

speaker: 911 OPERATOR
line: Please speak up.

speaker: LABONGE
line: No, I can't speak up. I... No, I can't!

speaker: 911 OPERATOR
line: Sir? Hello? Hello?

speaker: ALVAREZ
line: Son of a bitch.

speaker: LABONGE
line: Hey, partner. Hey, guys.

speaker: ALVAREZ
line: You son of a bitch.

speaker: LABONGE
line: I'm sorry?

speaker: ALVAREZ
line: You tried to frame me. Hijo de tu...

speaker: LABONGE
line: I didn't!

speaker: ALVAREZ
line: Oh, you didn't, huh?!

speaker: LABONGE
line: We've got a deal!

speaker: ALVAREZ
line: We got no deal. I'm gonna bleed you, you little bitch.

speaker: LABONGE
line: Back off!

speaker: ALVAREZ
line: You're dead.

speaker: COP
line: Freeze! Drop your weapon!

speaker: COP
line: Hands behind your head! Do it! Bring your head down. Spread your legs.

speaker: PINCHBECK
line: Agents. An unexpected surprise. Good afternoon.

speaker: SCULLY
line: We'd like to have a word with you, Mr. Pinchbeck.

speaker: PINCHBECK
line: I'm fairly busy, actually.

speaker: MULDER
line: I'll bet.

speaker: PINCHBECK
line: Hey! W-what...?

speaker: MULDER
line: Let's take a little spin, shall we?

speaker: PINCHBECK
line: What's this all about?

speaker: MULDER
line: It's about misdirection, Mr. Pinchbeck... or should I say the Amazing Maleeni?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder?!

speaker: MULDER
line: It's a trick, Scully. Voila.

speaker: PINCHBECK
line: Had you fooled.

speaker: SCULLY
line: You're Maleeni?

speaker: MALEENI/PINCHBECK
line: Call me Herman.

speaker: MALEENI/PINCHBECK
line: I was afraid for my life. That's why I did what I did. I'm not proud of that... but I owe a lot of money that I can't possibly pay back.

speaker: SCULLY
line: We know. Gambling debts to a man named Alvarez.

speaker: MALEENI/PINCHBECK
line: That tattooed psychopath. I've since heard terrible stories about him-- things he did in prison to fellow inmates.

speaker: SCULLY
line: So why'd you play poker with him?

speaker: MALEENI/PINCHBECK
line: He runs a good game. I gamble to supplement my income. God knows magic barely pays.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Well, why did you lose? You could have manipulated the cards, right?

speaker: MALEENI/PINCHBECK
line: Cheat? You're asking why I don't cheat at cards?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Well, you could, right?

speaker: MALEENI/PINCHBECK
line: Of course I could... … but how would I live with myself? Who raised you?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Well, sir... what does any of this have to do with your twin brother being found decapitated at the Santa Monica Pier?

speaker: MALEENI/PINCHBECK
line: I went to my brother for a loan. Just my luck-- and his.

speaker: SCULLY
line: You found him dead of a heart attack.

speaker: MALEENI/PINCHBECK
line: His body was still warm. Looking at him lifeless I saw myself-- my own eventual mortality. I saw all the things I meant to accomplish, but didn't. It was an opportunity to vanish-- to become someone else. Like I said, I'm... I'm not proud of what I did.

speaker: SCULLY
line: And so you refrigerated the body...

speaker: MALEENI/PINCHBECK
line: I needed time to figure out how to pull it all off. Impersonating my brother, I called the bank. Told them I needed a vacation week. A trip to Mexico. Then the bank received word that I'd been in a terrible accident. It gave me plenty of time away from work.

speaker: SCULLY
line: And you posed as an amputee to allay suspicion that you weren't your brother.

speaker: MALEENI/PINCHBECK
line: That, and I rather enjoyed the sympathy-- especially from the women in our office.

speaker: SCULLY
line: You, uh, still haven't explained why you left your brother's body at the pier or why you arranged to have his head fall off.

speaker: MALEENI/PINCHBECK
line: He explained it. He put it so eloquently when we last spoke. It was my final performance. I wanted to go out with such a shock, such a denouement as would forever be remembered in the annals of magic.

speaker: MULDER
line: That was your last performance.

speaker: MALEENI/PINCHBECK
line: What's this for?

speaker: MULDER
line: I still think you've got a few tricks up your sleeve.

speaker: BANK OFFICER
line: My god. We gave you handicapped parking. We built you a ramp.

speaker: MULDER
line: Did he have access to the vaults?

speaker: BANK OFFICER
line: Well, yes, he has a key to the day gate. Several of us do.

speaker: SCULLY
line: What are you looking for, Mulder?

speaker: MULDER
line: Any hint at all as to why Maleeni, here is really impersonating his brother. What about this. Could he have removed the funds electronically?

speaker: BANK OFFICER
line: Well, he didn't have security clearance for EFTs. Electronic fund transfers.

speaker: MULDER
line: Maybe he got around the security. Can we check the withdrawal records?

speaker: BANK OFFICER
line: It would require your badge number and thumbprint and probably a federal subpoena to boot.

speaker: BANK OFFICER
line: We're extra cautious with the EFTs. You can understand why. There may be an easier way. If I call up a transaction list for this terminal...

speaker: BANK OFFICER
line: No. No, everything's in order.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder, it says here something about a robbery attempt yesterday.

speaker: BANK OFFICER
line: Yeah, that wasn't against us but the armored transport service we deal with. No money was taken, and no suspects were caught.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Yeah, well, Mr. Pinchbeck was the employee who signed out the truck. He knew the schedule.

speaker: MALEENI/PINCHBECK
line: I had nothing to do with that.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Maybe, maybe not.

speaker: MULDER
line: We'll hold you till we find out. Make sure you don't pull a vanishing act.

speaker: HOLDING CELL OFFICER
line: Hey.

speaker: HOLDING CELL OFFICER
line: Paul, I'm putting Mr. Pinchbeck in six.

speaker: PAUL THE OTHER CELL OFFICER
line: Right.

speaker: HOLDING CELL OFFICER
line: Sleep tight.

speaker: MALEENI/PINCHBECK
line: Wait, don't I get a phone call, sir? Sir?

speaker: LABONGE
line: How'd it go?

speaker: MALEENI/PINCHBECK
line: Swimmingly.

speaker: LABONGE
line: Abracadabra, man.

speaker: BANK OFFICER
line: Oh, Deeaammnnn!!!

speaker: SCULLY
line: Yes... Okay. All right … All right, thank you.

speaker: MULDER
line: Maleeni?

speaker: SCULLY
line: He's still in the city lockup where he's been since we arrested him last night. It certainly doesn't look like he did this. Lots of fingerprints.

speaker: MULDER
line: Yeah. I guarantee you none of them match our thieves. They're too clever to leave clues... except for the ones they want us to find.

speaker: BANK OFFICER
line: Excuse me. May I show you something?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Yeah.

speaker: BANK OFFICER
line: We thought the security camera footage might show the robbers.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Does it?

speaker: BANK OFFICER
line: No. They all mysteriously went blank from about 3:00 A.M. to 3:20, but that's not what we wanted you to see.

speaker: ANTHONY THE COURIER GUARD
line: This is from two days ago.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Cissy Alvarez. Convicted bank robber.

speaker: ANTHONY THE COURIER GUARD
line: You recognize this man?

speaker: MULDER
line: Yeah. Who is he to you?

speaker: ANTHONY THE COURIER GUARD
line: I know those tattoos. That's the man who tried to rob my truck.

speaker: ALVAREZ
line: Ah! What the hell, man! What did I do?! You, FBI, what's up? What's up with this, man? Yo, man, you can't just come busting in here, okay? I got civil rights. I'm going to call my lawyer and then we're going to see what's what.

speaker: ANOTHER COP
line: There's nothing back there.

speaker: ALVAREZ
line: This is harassment, man. This is harassment! Yo, what are they looking for? Come on, man, yo! Somebody talk to me.

speaker: COP
line: Shut up.

speaker: ALVAREZ
line: You shut up. This ain't right. You got the cuffs on so tight. Yo, will you please tell me what he's looking for?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Well... saving up for a rainy day?

speaker: ALVAREZ
line: Oh, no, no, no, no. We got framed. This is a frame-up! That was the magician.

speaker: MULDER
line: The magician? Maleeni?

speaker: ALVAREZ
line: No. Not the dead one, man. That little cabron! LaBonge! LaBonge set me up! Listen to me...

speaker: SCULLY
line: Billy LaBonge.

speaker: MULDER
line: And the Amazing Maleeni. That's a double bill I wouldn't want to miss.

speaker: HOLDING CELL OFFICER
line: Pinchbeck. You made your bail. You too, LaBonge.

speaker: PAUL THE OTHER OFFICER AT THE BUZZER
line: Okay.

speaker: SCULLY
line: I think releasing these two may be a bit premature.

speaker: MULDER
line: Give us a minute, will you?

speaker: MULDER
line: Good morning, gentlemen. Did you sleep well?

speaker: MALEENI/PINCHBECK
line: Agent Mulder. Agent Scully.

speaker: MULDER
line: Bravo. Really.

speaker: LABONGE
line: What do you mean?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Last night the Cradock Marine Bank was robbed of $1.8 million. This morning that entire amount was found in the possession of Mr. Cissy Alvarez.

speaker: MALEENI/PINCHBECK
line: Wow. I told you he was bad news. Bravo to you. That was expeditious police work.

speaker: MULDER
line: Well, thank you. It was, wasn't it? It's only that Alvarez was so obviously guilty. A convicted bank robber caught red-handed witnessed trying to rob an armored car just two days earlier?

speaker: SCULLY
line: He'll need a good lawyer.

speaker: MULDER
line: Yeah. Yeah, he's up a creek... Just like you two want him.

speaker: MALEENI/PINCHBECK
line: I don't quite see where you're headed with this.

speaker: MULDER
line: I have no evidence but I have a theory, Mr. Maleeni and, uh, I'll tell you how it goes. I think that your twin brother, Albert, died of a heart attack at which point you and your young protégé saw a golden opportunity.

speaker: MALEENI/PINCHBECK
line: My protégé? I hate this guy's guts.

speaker: SCULLY
line: That's what you wanted us to think.

speaker: MULDER
line: You wanted revenge against the man who made your life in prison a living hell.

speaker: FLASHBACK OF LABONGE TALKING TO ALVAREZ
line: nan

speaker: LABONGE
line: I did time with you about eight years ago.

speaker: MULDER
line: Alvarez. You and he were in the same cell block eight years ago.

speaker: SCULLY
line: It was a setup from the start. You played poker with him and you made sure that you lost big.

speaker: MULDER
line: Which gave LaBonge and "in" with Alvarez once everybody thought you were dead.

speaker: SCULLY
line: LaBonge planted Alvarez's marker in Maleeni's van and made sure we found it … … and then you used Alvarez's greed in order to ensnare him and then orchestrated the attempted bank robbery in order to implicate him.

speaker: MULDER
line: Yeah. That was you in the armored car disguised as Alvarez. Somehow, Mr. Pinchbeck got ahold of the guard's gun and switched the clip. Guard didn't know it, but he was firing blanks.

speaker: SCULLY
line: And then last night the two of you robbed the bank, and planted the money at ALVAREZ's place.

speaker: LABONGE
line: Don't you think we have pretty good alibis?

speaker: MULDER
line: You have great alibis. You have the best alibis in the world which is why I think you two got arrested in the first place.

speaker: SCULLY
line: With your expertise at sleight of hand, pick pocketing, and escapology I think you were both able to get out of here by pilfering a guard's key.

speaker: MULDER
line: You could have escaped, stolen the money framed Alvarez and been back here in time for breakfast.

speaker: MALEENI/PINCHBECK
line: Scrambled eggs and sausage. That would be the world's greatest trick, wouldn't it?

speaker: MULDER
line: One that would be forever remembered in the annals of magic.

speaker: LABONGE
line: What happens to us?

speaker: MULDER
line: To you? You go free... provided the magic is over.

speaker: MALEENI/PINCHBECK
line: The great ones always know when to leave the stage. Billy, let's get the hell out of here.

speaker: MULDER
line: They are the world's greatest.

speaker: SCULLY
line: We saw through their magic.

speaker: MULDER
line: Nah, there's more.

speaker: MULDER
line: Behold! The Amazing Maleeni's wallet.

speaker: SCULLY
line: You picked his pocket?

speaker: MULDER
line: No. I pilfered it from the evidence room to prevent them from completing their final act of prestidigitation.

speaker: SCULLY
line: What are you talking about?

speaker: MULDER
line: I began to wonder, why did they need so elaborate a setup? Why so high profile? Why draw the attention of the FBI in the first place?

speaker: SCULLY
line: We were the last piece of the puzzle.

speaker: MULDER
line: Yes. Framing Alvarez was just another misdirection. This trick was about EFTs-- electronic funds transfers at the bank. Maleeni, Pinchbeck-- he didn't have security clearance for them so he needed a little federal law enforcement intervention-- specifically, my badge number... … and my thumbprint. With those two items, they could pull off an EFT and steal enough electronically as to make that $1.8 million look like cigar-lighting money. But they can't do it without this. Pick a card, Scully... Any card.

speaker: SCULLY
line: You know, Mulder, there's still one thing that you haven't explained.

speaker: MULDER
line: What's that?

speaker: SCULLY
line: How the Amazing Maleeni was able to turn his head completely around.

speaker: MULDER
line: I don't know that.

speaker: SCULLY
line: I do. I'll show you. Observe.

speaker: MULDER
line: Gee! Very nice. How'd you do that?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Well... magic.

speaker: MULDER
line: No. Seriously, Scully, how'd you do it? You know, it's not the same thing. It's different with the head. Come on. Look at this.

speaker: MULDER
line: I'll show you - - -
